trs: Tomorrow, \textbf{s/he will go} to school.’ [Note that in other dialects, \textit{mu-gamba} refers to ‘morning’.] \z
All \textbf{will find} a crown (in heaven).’ (Funeral song, ln 5)
The roads \textbf{will be} good (in heaven).’ (Funeral song, ln 7)

src: Zi-seendi   zi-ra,     \textbf{zi-ra-ku-koɲ-a}   kʊ   vi-indo   vivj-o       vi-ra.
trs: That money, \textbf{it will help you} with those things of yours.’ (B. E. cow care, ln 69)
Again, \textbf{it will give you} milk.’ (B. E. cow care, ln 45)
It is good, because \textbf{you will sell} of it.’ (B. E. cow care, ln 80)
\textbf{it will bring} trouble for you.’ (B. E. cow care, ln 130)
The cow \textbf{will not deny you} milk.’ (B. E. cow care, ln 32)
but \textbf{they will not be able to}.’ (Funeral song, lns 11-12)
\textbf{They will not find} any presents.’ (Funeral song, ln 13)
And she said, the person who breaks it just a little,
\textbf{I will take her} to the ogre.’ (Funeral song, lns 11-13)
\textbf{We will award, we will award} our Mike flowers.’ (Praise song, ln 1)
They replied (that) \textbf{they will finish}.
She gave (the wings) to them and they knitted (them) and finished.
She told them, (since) you have knitted my wings,
what \textbf{will you give me}?
They took a goat and gave (it) to her and she went.’ (G. O. woman and hen, lns 16-17)

src: Mu-kana   mu-rara   neva   \textbf{a-raka-ataɲ-e}   kʊ     ɪ-sjoŋgo   ɪ-jɪ,
trs: One girl, if \textbf{she will break} a pot,
\textbf{I will take her} to the ogre.’ (H. M. woman and eight girls, lns 6-7)

src: A-a!  Mama    a-m-bol-e      ndɪ   mu-ndʊ   \textbf{u-raka-ataɲ-e}   kʊ   ɪ-sjoŋgo
trs: Uh-uh! Mother told me that a person \textbf{who will break} a pot,
\textbf{she will take her} to the ogre, who will go to eat her.' (H. M. woman and eight girls, lns 11-12)
S/he will do work (after tomorrow).
\textbf{S/he will do} work (at a later date).
\textbf{you milk it}…’ (B. E. cow care, lns 27-29)
Now, \textbf{s/he is going} to drink coffee.
Tomorrow, \textbf{I will go} to school.
\textbf{You will find} in it milk as you desire.’ (B. E. cow care ln 31)
\textbf{I will go} to the farm, I will pick rikove,’ (C. C. lunchtime ln 6)
Once (the greens) have shriveled, \textbf{it will arrive at}, close to eleven o’clock,
twelve o'clock, then I will put (it) on the stove.’ (lns 13-16)
Once I've put water on, \textbf{I will make the cornmeal}.’ (lns 37-38)
So \textbf{you know} when (the cow) passes by a person,
it will not hit him.’ (B. E. cow care, ln 133)

src: Ma,   nɪ-kʊ-tʊr-a     jo,  ma   va-ande     nɪ-va-zj-a…
trs: Then, we left there, then the others went…’ (M. I. today tomorrow lns 21-22)
The boy and the girl \textbf{made a wedding}.’ (G. O. girls who wanted luck, ln 78)
He found the dog at home.
\textbf{He took} that dog,
and started to stay with it.’ (G. O. girls who wanted luck lns 39-41)
Then tomorrow \textbf{I will wake up}, \textbf{then I will go} to another job.’ (M. I. today, tomorrow ln 62)
\textbf{I will uproot (it)} together with \textit{umutere}, \textbf{then I will separate the leaves from the stems}.’ (C. C. lunchtime lns 7-8)
As for the barns,\footnote{‘Barns’ here apparently refers to grain storage; rather than store food outside, it is now being stored indoors.} we have put (them) in the houses: thieves.

src: va-ku-n̪o   kʊ-no,   ʊ-kob-e     zi-kwiiri,   na   va-ku-temag-aa.
trs: They find you there; cry out, and they are chopping you.
\textbf{(Thus) we have put (them)} in the eating area.’ (\citealt{NicholsSsennyonga1976}, barns lns 1-3)
